ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
- learning about various racial projects
- learning about
Critical writing; close reading; learning about the concepts of postblackness, afrofuturism, film blackness, etc.
I learned a lot about Blackness and developed a skill at understanding culture through a historical and analytical lens.
How to critically analyze a text and place my own thoughts into conversation with it.
What post-blackness is, different black aesthetics, what makes a black aesthetics and how to build on other peoples comments in a seminar

This class was my first experience discussing literature, especially contemporary works, in a really impactful and high-level way. So I learned a lot about how to have those discussions...what's important, what language to use, as well as the actual content of ongoing literary discourses. I'm still not entirely sure I completely and accurately understand some of the frameworks we spent time talking about (maybe that's just the nature of artistic criticism), but I walked away having learned a lot about the way race and blackness show up in media.
How to write essays
To read theory critically and form my own theories on thoughts on blackness.
I learned a lot about black aesthetics and how they manifest in different types of Black media: literature, film, music, art

I improved my writing skills by learning to break away from standard essay formats. I also learned to critically read and analyze different kinds of texts including novels, plays, poems, and films. I learned so much about the history and future of Black art, culture, and literature. I learned about different modes of thinking surrounding these areas and areas of conflict between scholars.

This class equipped with a repertoire of vocabulary, literature, and works of art that allow you to think about Blackness in a new way. Whether you are reading scholarship that legitimizes your experience or learning about the complex role of race, this class always keeps you engaged. Students brought challenging statements and the professor created room for disagreements and discussion. This is a very insightful class!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Good balance between structured time with the professor talking and the students talking. I think if we could go through TQEs more quickly, people can discuss with the larger group more.

Strengths: The collaborative presentation assignment; highlighting different Black creative forms (music, art, film, etc.) although this class did focus on writing; the format of contextualizing content with slides at the beginning of class then going into further discussion on the texts for the rest of class; TQE discussion format 

Weaknesses: Sometimes the readings were fairly dense and sometimes we didn't get time in class to fully talk about them, so it felt like I was wasting my free time reading and trying to understand texts that we wouldn't certainly discuss in class.

strengths: the teacher is very receptive to feedback 

weaknesses: the texts tend to be really dense and I didn't go into the class with enough background knowledge to feel fully ready

Strengths: classroom vibes, readings were engaging, Professor Edwards is amazing!
Only 1 Weakness: 9am time (it was hard waking up on time)

Strength: every seminar was engaging and you walked away learning something 
Weakness: some of the readings would be difficult to understand

I think the syllabus for this course is really incredible and introduced me to a lot of amazing texts I'm not sure I would have found on my own. I also think the dynamic of the class and the discussion was really special. Everyone was always so engaged and had a lot of insight to offer. I think from time to time I was a little unsure of the overall direction or goals of the class (like I mentioned above I'm not sure I have the "right" understanding of some of the concepts we were talking about), but I'm also not sure that matters because I know I learned a lot from and really really enjoyed taking the class.

Strengths: the discussion style- every class was a new and exciting topic to discuss
Weaknesses- none

Great discussions in class, great variety in texts and good projects+essays.

9 am time was personally brutal  if this class was at any later time i would have loved it even more.

A strength of this course is that it exposes students to a diverse array of sources and is also centered around discussions which allows students to really share our ideas. The only weakness was that at times the readings felt overwhelming but Professor Edwards did a good job of addressing our concerns about this

Strengths: This course was heavily discussion based and surrounded a different text every week or two. We also often structured our classes around TQEs (Thoughts, Questions, and Epiphanies) which allowed our discussions to cater to our own inquiries and curiosities. All of the texts we covered were incredibly engaging and reading every text was genuinely enjoyable. The secondary texts we'd read which were usually essays and scholarly articles were, while sometimes challenging, very enlightening and provided nuance to the texts and topics we were covering in class each week. At the end of the course, students formulate a portfolio that contains all of their writings from the semester as well as reflections. The portfolio style of the course really centers student learning and growth over simply adhering to a rubric to achieve a certain grade. 

Weaknesses: Not necessarily a weakness but if you're someone who learns best with more structure to discussions, you may find this class to be very heavily led by student insights. Discussions are very fluid and while there are distinct texts and topics we cover every class, there isn't necessarily a rigid structure, which works very well for some and perhaps not as well for others.

Strengths: The class offers a lot of flexibility when deciding what art medium students can write about. The musically inclined, theatre enthusiasts, or literature buffs can choose to write about a medium that better suits them. Class discusses a wide variety of art forms that prove relevant throughout the entire semester

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! We cover a variety of stimulating topics under the umbrella of post-blackness. There's something for everyone and we all bring different perspectives to the table in a beautiful way.
Yes. You'll learn a lot about this very interesting topic and likely grow as a writer.
Yes I would, if they're curious about Black aesthetics and the function of Blackness as a literary and pop-cultural tool.
YES!!!!
Yes, it's an amazing class to build your writing skills in and to learn how to engage in seminars
Absolutely! The readings are amazing and I always learned a ton from the discussion. I think because everything is so contemporary, you never question why anything matters, it's always so clear.
Yes a million times yes. This is a great WR credit and an even more amazing professor
Absolutely. If you have any interest in African-American studies or just blackness in general, this is a great class to take.
I would definitely recommend this course to students who are interested in African American literature and art

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Personally, I haven't been given the opportunity to study Black art and culture in an academic setting, and this level of critical engagement was incredibly enlightening. The texts we read are fruitful and not one-sided. Authors disagree, and there is a level of nuance in basically every text and topic we cover that had me constantly changing my mind and rethinking. Moreover, the first-year seminar style of this course makes for a very comfortable environment where students are encouraged to share their thoughts, disagree, and bounce off one another.
This is a great course that creates a space for you to rethink the world around you. You learn so much about yourself and others in the context of society.
